explanation: Alpha decay is a type of radioactive decay where an atomic nucleus emits an alpha particle (helium-4 nucleus) consisting of two protons and two neutrons. This process occurs in heavy nuclei to reduce their mass and achieve greater stability. The decay energy Q determines the kinetic energies of the products and governs the decay probability through quantum tunneling.

assumptions.text: The alpha particle exists as a bound unit within the parent nucleus.
The decay products separate to infinite distance (complete separation).
Conservation of energy and momentum apply to the decay process.
The parent nucleus is initially at rest in the laboratory frame.
Nuclear recoil energy is much smaller than the Q-value for heavy nuclei.

derivation.description: Apply conservation of energy to the decay process, including rest masses and kinetic energies.
derivation.equation: Conservation of energy: M_parent c^2 = M_daughter c^2 + M_alpha c^2 + T_daughter + T_alpha

derivation.description: Define the Q-value as the energy available for kinetic energy of the products.
derivation.equation: Q_alpha = T_daughter + T_alpha = (M_parent - M_daughter - M_alpha) c^2

derivation.description: Apply conservation of momentum: the products must have equal and opposite momenta.
derivation.equation: Conservation of momentum: vec p_daughter + vec p_alpha = 0

derivation.description: Since momentum is conserved and initial momentum is zero, final momenta are equal in magnitude.
Express kinetic energies in terms of momentum for non-relativistic particles.
derivation.equation: T_daughter = p^2/(2 M_daughter), T_alpha = p^2/(2 M_alpha)

derivation.description: Relate the total kinetic energy to the momentum using reduced mass concepts.
derivation.equation: Q_alpha = p^2/(2 M_daughter) + p^2/(2 M_alpha) = p^2/2 (1/M_daughter + 1/M_alpha)

derivation.description: Determine the alpha particle kinetic energy from momentum conservation.
The decay rate depends exponentially on quantum tunneling through the Coulomb barrier.
derivation.equation: lambda_alpha prop exp(-2 G) where G = Gamow factor

limitations: Limited to nuclei where alpha decay is energetically favorable
Tunneling probability calculations require detailed nuclear models
May compete with other decay modes

historical_context.importance: First type of radioactivity discovered, led to understanding of nuclear structure and quantum tunneling
